title: 110_hr7019
content: The Act is titled the "Middle Class College Tuition Tax Credit Expansion Act of 2008" and it amends Section 25A of the Internal Revenue Code to provide a credit for qualified tuition and related expenses. The "Middle Class College Tuition Tax Credit Expansion Act of 2008" allows eligible individuals to claim a tax credit of 50% of qualified tuition and related expenses, up to $10,000 per academic period. There are limitations based on modified adjusted gross income. The tax credit amount is determined based on the taxpayer's modified adjusted gross income for the taxable year, with a maximum of $5,000 ($10,000 for joint returns). Modified adjusted gross income is defined as the taxpayer's adjusted gross income for the year. The taxpayer's gross income for the taxable year is increased by any excluded amounts under specific sections. A joint return has an applicable amount of 200% of the dollar amount under subparagraph (B), while other cases have a set amount of $100,000. The credit is allowed for only 4 taxable years, and definitions are provided for clarity. The term 'eligible individual' refers to individuals meeting specific criteria, and 'qualified tuition and related expenses' include tuition, fees, and books required for enrollment at an eligible educational institution for the taxpayer, spouse, or dependents. The term 'eligible educational institution' refers to an institution where qualified tuition and related expenses, including books required for academic courses, are incurred. Expenses related to sports, games, hobbies, nonacademic fees like student activity fees, athletic fees, insurance expenses, or other unrelated expenses are not included. An eligible educational institution, as defined by the Taxpayer Relief Act of 1997, must be described in section 481 of the Higher Education Act of 1965 and eligible for participation in a program under title IV of the same Act. Taxpayers claiming a credit for an eligible student must include the student's name and taxpayer identification number on their tax return. Adjustments may be made for scholarships affecting qualified tuition and related expenses. The account for an individual's academic period is reduced by amounts paid for the individual's benefit, including qualified scholarships, educational assistance allowances, and payments for educational expenses. Treatment of qualified tuition and related expenses paid by a dependent when a deduction is allowed to another taxpayer in the same calendar year. Treatment of qualified tuition and related expenses paid by the taxpayer during the first 3 months following the taxable year. No double benefit allowed for expenses deducted elsewhere. Married individuals must file joint returns for the credit to apply. Nonresident aliens are also eligible. Nonresident aliens can qualify for the tax credit if they are treated as resident aliens by making an election under specific sections. The $100,000 amount in subsection (b)(1)(D)(ii) will be adjusted for inflation for taxable years starting after 2009. The Secretary may prescribe regulations for the tax credit, including recapture in cases of refunds. The deduction for qualified tuition expenses is repealed, and related amendments are made to the tax code. The tax code is amended by striking various paragraphs and clauses related to different sections. The tax code is amended by striking sections and inserting new references. Eligible student criteria are updated to include specific requirements from the Higher Education Act of 1965. Subclause (I) of section 529 is also modified. The tax code is amended by updating references in various sections. Section 529, 530, and 1400O are all modified to reflect new references. Subparagraph (J) of section 6213 is also amended. Subparagraph (J) of section 6213(g)(2) of the tax code is amended to replace "section 25A(g)(1)" with "section 25A(d)(1)". Additionally, the table of sections for subpart A of part IV of subchapter A of chapter 1 is updated by removing the item related to section 25A and adding a new entry. The tax code is amended to remove the item related to section 222 and replace it with a new entry. The changes apply to expenses paid after December 31, 2008, for education starting after that date.
